title: Taiwan’s Xing Fu Tang is fighting online with its Malaysian franchisee – and it’s allegedly over heart-shaped boba machines worth RM4.5 million
text:
The Xing Fu Tang dispute has gotten ugly, with both sides publishing damning posts about one another. Rachel Chia/Business Insider

Taiwanese bubble tea brand Xing Fu Tang is now in a public war with its Malaysia master franchisee, Collab Working Lifestyle.

The two companies used their respective Facebook pages to post long and strongly worded accusations about each other’s behaviour.

Xing Fu Tang Taiwan called Collab Working Lifestyle a greedy partner who breached contract terms to squeeze out profits from outlet owners.

Collab Working Lifestyle said Xing Fu Tang Taiwan was defaming it in retaliation for refusing to pay RM4.5 million for 34 special machines to make strawberry flavoured, heart-shaped boba.

Netizens said that the spectacle reminded them of last year’s ugly dispute between Chatime and Tealive.

Thirty-four boba machines worth RM4.5 million are now at the centre of an ugly public spat between Taiwanese bubble tea chain Xing Fu Tang and its Malaysian master franchisee, Collab Working Lifestyle, whose working relationship looks to be on the brink of collapse.

Online, many netizens commented on the similarity of this saga to last year’s high-profile franchise dispute between Chatime and Tealive, with many calling it deja vu.

Both companies have since taken to Facebook to post lengthy and strongly-worded accusations about each other’s behaviour.

The first post, published by Xing Fu Tang Taiwan last Monday (Oct 21), accused Collab Working Lifestyle of breaching contractual terms to earn itself extra profits.

It threatened to terminate its master franchisee contract, adding that it was “heartbroken” to have its reputation “smeared” by a “greedy” partner.

According to Xing Fu Tang, its Taiwan HQ had received numerous complaints about the master franchisee from outlet owners in Malaysia.

Among them were accusations that Collab Working Lifestyle did not help sub-franchisees set up their outlets, but only provided a couple of photos and print-outs.

In addition, it shipped them bubble tea ingredients at unreasonable prices, and even publicly said it did this “because it could”.

Collab Working Lifestyle lied to sub-franchisees that it would only allocate one bubble tea outlet per zone, and even charged them monthly marketing and brand maintenance fees, instead of only once a year per the contract, the post added.

Xing Fu Tang said the fees Collab Working Lifestyle demanded far exceeded the sum it paid master franchisee rights to the whole Malaysia.

Last, the Taiwanese brand called out Collab Working Lifestyle for hatching plans to set up its own bubble tea brand with Xing Fu Tang’s Indian franchisee, adding that both these franchisees had failed to meet contractual obligations.

“We are deeply concerned about the livelihood of our Malaysian sub-franchisees once the new brand is established,” the post added.

In the week Xing Fu Tang Taiwan’s post was published, two outlets in Klang Valley were vandalised with red paint five times.

“We have lodged police reports and submitted the CCTV footage to authorities. We don’t know who did it, but we refuse to bow to thugs,” Xing Fu Tang Malaysia said.

❌ Defamation ❌Compromising We will not bow to thugs ‼️From Oct 17 to 26, two Xing Fu Tang stores in Klang Valley… Posted by Xing Fu Tang Malaysia 馬來西亞幸福堂 on Monday, 28 October 2019

“Our conscience is clear”: Malaysia master franchisee

Days after the incident, Collab Working Lifestyle responded with its own Facebook post on sunday (Oct 27) on the Xing Fu Tang Malaysia page.

It accusing the Taiwanese business of defaming it as retaliation for refusing to buy expensive boba machines.

According to the post, Xing Fu Tang’s principal company, CEO International, had on Oct 15 asked its Malaysia business to order 34 special machines to make strawberry heart-shaped boba.

The machines, due to be delivered between end 2020 and 2021, cost RM4.5 million in total, with payment due on Oct 16, it said.

Describing the price tag as “sky high”, Collab Working Lifestyle said it called for a meeting of all Malaysian sub-franchisees, and the group collectively decided not to buy therm.

They then sent a letter, signed by all Malaysian franchisees, to inform CEO International of the desicion.

In its post, Collab Working Lifestyle added it had previously bought induction cookers for RM40,000 each and egg cake machines for RM150,000 each, despite having no egg cakes on the menu.

It claimed CEO International often sold them “drastically inflated” equipment, such as track lights and machines that often broke down.

Collab Working Lifestyle also called Xing Fu Tang Taiwan’s various accusations “unfounded” and “wild”, but acknowledged it did have plans to start its own bubble tea brand.

It did this for “business survival”, as its its ten-year master franchisee agreement was now under threat, it said.

“Our conscience is clear. We have not breached the master franchise agreement,” the post read. “As Malaysian SMEs, we have invested a lot of resources into the Xing Fu Tang brand, and we will not be bullied.”

Addressing fans, it added: “Xing Fu Tang Malaysia will continue to operate as usual. We will continue to serve you your favourite drinks.”
